awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exchange and Dispersion Across the Inner Shelf: Understanding the Importance of Spatial Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
This study seeks to understand spatial variability in the flow field over the inner part of the continental shelf at scales of 100s of meters to 10s of kilometers, its contribution to exchange and dispersion, and its implications for coastal systems. Recent observations of the coastal ocean south of Martha's Vineyard, MA have documented startling examples of spatially-variable flows with the potential to drive focused lateral exchange across the shelf rivaling that due to the frequently-examined along-shelf uniform response to upwelling or downwelling.  Yet, we know almost nothing about the characteristics of the flow field at these scales because conventional observational techniques and typical realistic shelf models do not adequately resolve these scales. This will likely be the first comprehensive study of current variability in the coastal ocean at scales from 100s of meters to 10s of kilometers by employing a unique combination of high-resolution HF radar surface currents, dense observations of subsurface velocity and hydrography, and mass drifter releases along with comparisons to realistic and idealized numerical models. The proposed work will quantify the total flux of water masses across the shelf, the relative importance of spatial variability in the wind, stratification, and bathymetry on exchange, and the role of spatially-variable dispersion.

Previous efforts to quantify the rates of exchange in the coastal ocean have generally focused on the transport due to along-shelf uniform, wind-driven dynamics. While evidence of additional transport due to major capes or headlands, bathymetric irregularities, or non-uniform wind fields has been found in most coastal areas, the relative impact of these sources of variability on exchange and dispersion across the shelf have not been quantified. Additionally, the effects of small-scale and/or transient features, potentially important sources of spatially-dependent exchange or dispersion, have never been resolved. This comprehensive view of exchange across the coastal ocean south of Martha's Vineyard, including the use of Lagrangian trajectory analyses in addition to the Eulerian-based transport studies, will enable a much broader range of spatial variability to be captured and will quantify the occurrence of transient events, their drivers, and their importance for coastal systems.

The movement of water masses from the shallow waters adjacent to the coast to the larger coastal ocean offshore controls the flux of heat, salt, nutrients, and pollutants between the nearshore and the global ocean. By providing a holistic look at across-shelf transport, the results of this work will document the potential effects of spatial variability on coastal systems. This effort will improve our ability to quantify and predict the exchange critical to assessing the productivity of coastal areas and the dispersion rates critical to monitoring the fate of harmful algal blooms, pollutants, and search and rescue operations. The PIs are actively involved in teaching and mentoring at WHOI and UMASS Dartmouth as well as interacting with coastal managers and planners. In collaboration with the NOAA's Northeast Fisheries Science Center, a broad educational program will entrain K-12 students in the region into the science being conducted through additional drifter deployments

por.por_cntn:
Major goal of this project is to understand current variability at scales of kilometers and the role of this spatial variability on exchange and dispersion over the inner part of the continental shelf and its implications for the study area and other coastal systems.  The project was carried out  through a comprehensive field program over the inner and mid-shelf south of Martha’s Vineyard (MV), MA. The field program will include high-resolution HF radar-based surface currents, satellite SSTs, an array of in situ velocity and hydrographic moorings, and two mass drifter releases. The observations from this field program were combined with a high-resolution numerical model simulation to quantify the scales of variability present, their drivers, and investigate the relative importance of non-uniform responses to wind forcing, tidal rectified flow, and small-scale eddy features on the total exchange across the inner shelf.  The specific objectives for model-drifter and model-CODAR comparisons are to 1) examine if a high-resolution hydrostatic model is capable of resolving a meso-to small scale current variability observed in both CODAR and drifters, 2) identify major physical processes that caused the model uncertainty and 3) provide insights into using the CODAR-derived flow field to calibrate the initial field for the forecast operations.

Model-data comparison results show that a high-resolution model is capable of reproducing the energies and amplitudes of CODAR-derived semi-diurnal (M2, N2 and S2) and diurnal (K1 and O1) tidal flow over the southern shelf of  MV. A relatively large uncertainty in the CODAR-derived current direction could lead a large mismatch in tidal orientation and phase. The subtidal currents observed by the CODAR over the southern shelf of MV  are characterized by tidal residual and wind-driven flow and meso-scale eddies. The agreement of the model-computed and CODAR-derived near-surface currents varied with time-scale. The mismatch was large for hourly averaged flows and reduced significantly for monthly averaged flows. The high-resolution model is capable of reproducing the general circulation pattern observed by CODAR, with errors appearing mainly in the current directions. This is consistent with large measurement uncertainties in the direction of CODAR-derived currents. The model-computed and CODAR-detected eddies significantly differed in number, but similar in the distribution regarding these parameters. The model-computed and CODAR-detected cyclonic eddies appeared in similar zones, but the model-computed eddies were smaller in size and less in number.  There were two types of eddies detected by both CODAR and model. One was the tidal flushing eddies and another was wind-induced eddies. The model seemed to be able to reasonably capture the tidal-flushing cyclonic eddies, but not for the wind-induced anti-cyclonic eddies.  The model-produced trajectories followed the trend of observed drifters, but mismatch errors increased with time.  Using Fickian’s formula to estimate the drifter-derived and model particle-produced horizontal diffusions, they exhibited the same variability pattern and in the same order in the first three-tracking days. The model simulation results show that both anti-cyclonic and cyclonic eddies over the southern shelf of MV are surface-intensified, but their radius increased with depth. In this shallow region, spatial structures of either tidal flushing or wind-induced eddies are bottom friction dependent, suggesting that the generation, intensity and distribution of these eddies are sensitive to the turbulence parameterization in the model. 

Model-CODAR comparison experiments suggest that it is premature to include the CODAR-derived near-surface currents in data assimilation.  Since the uncertainty of CODAR-derived flow direction is relatively large, directly assimilating CODAR-derived flow into the model may turn the true flow to the unrealistic flow due to a big bias in the direction measurement of CODAR. Instead, one could assimilate the CODAR-derived flow speed into the model to calibrate the initial flow field for forecast operations.
